sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Moscow responds to the US's security proposals in writing as NATO accuses Russia of deploying more troops to Ukraine's borders.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Ukraine condemns shelling in the east of the country, accusing Russian-backed separatists in Donbass of hitting a school.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: in Donbass of hitting a school.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Withdrawing from Mali, French President Emmanuel Macron announces that French and European troops will leave the country, citing growing hostility from the governing military junta.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And claims that more Polish opposition figures were illegally targeted using Pegasus spyware.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We'll have the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Thanks for joining me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: US President Joe Biden and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson say that Russia could be launching a false flag attack after reports of shelling in eastern Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Ukrainian officials say a school in the Donbass region was hit by tank fire from Russian-backed separatists.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Foreign Minister Dmitry Kuleba confirmed there were no fatalities, but said that the attack violated the Minsk agreements.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Moscow says there was an exchange of fire between government forces and rebels and blamed the Ukrainian side for firing first.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The Kremlin also deny that they're planning to invade Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This increase in tensions in the region follows NATO's second day of meetings to address the Russia-Ukraine crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg maintains that Moscow's military buildup is not normal activity and that there's been no withdrawal of troops.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That's despite the Kremlin insisting it is pulling back its military from the border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: However, U.S. Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin says more military units have moved in.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: LLOYD AUSTIN, U.S. Secretary of in. We see some of those troops inch closer to that border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We see them fly in more combat and support aircraft.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We see them sharpen their readiness in the Black Sea.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We even see them stocking up their blood supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: You know, I was a soldier myself not that long ago, and I know firsthand that you don't do these sort of things for no reason.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And you certainly don't do them if you're getting ready to pack up and go home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, for more on this, let's cross over to Brussels now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We can speak to our correspondent Maeve McMahon. Maeve to begin with we understand that Russia has now responded to the US's security proposals in writing what do we know at this stage? Good evening Helena well we do understand that Russia has sent a written letter to the US delegation regarding these security concerns. We spoke to the US ambassador to NATO regarding this very letter and she confirmed that they had received it. That said, she did shy away from revealing the contents of that letter saying that it should be up to Russia to do so and she also pointed out, and this is what a lot of sources at NATO over the last two days have been saying as well, that one can be sending letters to and fro for the next couple of months but what really needs to happen what really needs to happen very very soon is that both sides sit down around the table to discuss exactly what's going on and try and find a diplomatic way out despite having instead of having letters that can be misinterpreted um different by different ways by by both sides mave you also sat down today with NATO Chief Jens Stoltenberg on the very day that essentially NATO has accused Russia of lying about its troop numbers and its deployments.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: What did he have to tell you?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: I did indeed, and that's the second time I sat down

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: with the NATO Chief Jens Stoltenberg in just a couple of weeks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And the last time I spoke to him It felt like the mood was a little bit more optimistic But today he felt he told me that the trust in Russia was at its lowest that it's been for a very very long time That none of the NATO allies even knew yet what the intentions of Vladimir Putin were but that they were very very concerned about them And that's why the focus of that meeting over the last two days was how NATO can defend itself better and about og er veldig bekymret for dem. Det er derfor fokuset på denne møtene de siste to dagerne var hvordan NATO kan bestå seg bedre, og om å oppføre støtte i den nordlige Europa, om å oppføre og sende flere trupper til ulike land der i hvert fall det skulle være en attackering.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Vi kan nå ta en løsning til Jens Sturtenberg, som snakket med meg tidligere på NATO-H-kvarteret.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Han brukte en frasje, jeg tror det var på mandag eller tidligere i denne uka, at jeg var nødvendig optimistisk.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Det var basert på det vi så, på visningene fra Moskva, at de var klar til å ta et diplomatisk forsøk.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Vi tror fortidig i NATO at vi bør sitte ned i Russien og finne en politisk løsning, en politisk vei frem.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Men vi har sett at det ikke har skjedd noen følgeopp på grunnen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Vi har ikke sett noen forløp av krefter, noen deeskalasjon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Og selvfølgelig må Russland gjøre hva de sier, og det er faktisk å forløpe krefter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Og det blir å se. Før vi ser en virkelig utfordring, blir det en permanent trekk over russisk invasjon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: En skeptisk Jens Stoltenberg, NATO-sekretar, som snakket litt tidligere.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Hvordan åpner NATO-allier seg for dialog og en diplomatisk utgangspunkt i dette?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Maeve McMahon har et that sit-down interview with NATO Chief Jens Stoltenberg.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Maeve, thank you for your reporting.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, in Kiev for us tonight is our correspondent, Sasha Vakulina, and we can speak to Sasha now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Sasha, to begin with, regards to that shelling in Donbass.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: NATO has warned it could be part of a false flag operation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: What is the sense there in Ukraine?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: NATO has warned it could be part of a false flag operation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: What is the sense there in Ukraine?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine's president, called the Shalykovo kindergarten, Stanitsa Luhanska, a big provocation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And he said that this is why, exactly because of the cases like this, this is why the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe should keep its monitoring mission, should keep its delegates and diplomats in Ukraine, because their monitoring activities are an additional deterrent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Over the past week or so, we have heard from many countries their calls on the citizens to leave Ukraine immediately because of the possible attack that was the US, UK and other countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And some of those nationals are, of course, the members of those monitoring missions of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and this is why it is important for them to stay there and not to leave the country right now whether this could be a false flag at a time poor administrator Abba said that this might be but also he said that Ukraine is very much ready for anything and he insisted that this is why Kiev and Ukraine are cooperating with the international partners to make sure that such attempts fail.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well, what about those efforts with international partners then, specifically with NATO, for example?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: What are Ukraine's NATO ambitions?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Because President Zelensky said today that this was a goal and not a dream, and it seems that that position has been moving quite a bit in recent days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Since the Euromaidan, the revolution of dignity, 2014, that happened right behind me here at the Independence Square, Ukrainians only increased the way they want to join the NATO and the European Union. This is not really a choice for them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: There is no option when they would say, when they would admit that they cannot join the alliance and they cannot join the European Union.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: This is why all the rhetoric now about whether Ukraine can join the EU and NATO, whether it's just a dream, there is no scenario in which Ukraine's president, Volodymyr Zelensky, can come here on the square and tell the people of Ukraine that Ukraine is not going to join NATO.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And with everything that's been happening since 2014 and with the recent escalation in the past few weeks, I can tell you Ukrainians only wanted more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: All right, Sasha Vakulina putting everything into context for us from Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Sasha, thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: After almost a decade, France and its European partners are to withdraw their troops from Mali.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: President Emmanuel Macron made the announcement following a meeting of European and African leaders at the Elysee Palace.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The pullout will be done over a four to six month period in coordination with the Malian military.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: France first deployed troops against jihadists in the country in 2013 and while successful in stemming the extremists' advance, in recent years militant groups have taken over swathes of territory in the former French colony.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: France intervened in Mali, firstly to fight against terrorism, second at the request of a sovereign state and the states of the region. In this second condition, that is changing today and victory in the face of terrorism. It is not possible if it is not supported by the state itself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And why did we decide today to leave? Because the hunter which is in charge of Mali no longer makes it its priority.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well for more on what the implications of this withdrawal could be let's bring in security expert Declan Power now. Declan good to have you with us this evening. To begin with it appears to be a somewhat hasty exit. What could the implications be for anti-terror operations in the region?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: for anti-terror operations in the region?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, I think that the standard operational footprint of Western forces there will initially be unaffected. But in the long term, a country like France has a huge amount to contribute, not just to the visuals that you see of French troops on patrol, but in what will be known as over theizon support in terms of intelligence, in terms of logistics, and other things that are essential to the long-term running of such a mission. And it remains to be seen if they will still be engaged in that. As I understand it, they're still going to stay in the Sahel region, so they probably will still be able to provide some assistance to the UN mission that will still be there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I think perhaps it may be a clever move for France in the long term, as they're in an antagonistic relationship at the moment with the Malian regime.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: They don't want to be seen, I suppose, to be propping up a military junta that sees power in a coup.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Junta that seized power in a coup. And also France was increasingly becoming a target for, I suppose, mismanaged West African expectations in many respects. And this gives them a chance, gives French foreign policy a chance to regroup and reignite its relationship with that part of Africa on a more positive footing, because it has been deteriorating at a diplomatic level in a negative way for some years now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: A difficult relationship, as you say there, with the regime.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But what about the people that they leave behind?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: What about the region?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I mean, is there the risk that the withdrawal could actually give ground to terror groups, terror groups which have already killed thousands, left millions of people displaced in the region well some cynics would say that during the period they've been there that attacks have continued and that the much expected stability uh that the french-led uh mission was supposed to bring didn't work so could could things be any worse? There is a possibility if you were to apply a little bit of counterintuitive thinking that by the French pulling out that it might it might calm the situation a little bit in allowing the other Western forces there, the UN mission in particular, maybe enhance their footprint. There is still, maybe enhance their footprint.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: There is still, there will be still a number of other troops there, including a German battle group, of which some of my own countrymen are serving in a small special forces component.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And it would maybe allow us to see how the Malian forces themselves will cope.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I mean, a big part of the Western contribution, including the EU contribution, was to train up Malian forces to be able to take the fight to the rebels and to be able to stabilise their own country. If that isn't proven to be the case, then it argues for maybe a reconfigured, maybe French-led or French-participated in force going back in. But at the moment, I don't think it can necessarily do any harm in the long term for France's policies. I think it gives them a chance to regroup and reinvent the relationship because things are in a sort of a stalemate and the French forces on the ground were increasingly becoming targets. So again, you could argue that they were a part of an inflammatory process there at the moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: All right, Declan Power, security expert, good to get your insights.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Still to come, women win big at the Berlinale. We'll be taking a look at the films grabbing the gold and silver bears after the break.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews tonight. Welcome back.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Two more Polish opposition figures have been illegally hacked using Pegasus software.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That's according to Amnesty International.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now, the growing scandal over the Israeli-owned spyware has led to calls for European-wide action.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And we can find out now more from Matthew in the Cube.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Indeed, Helena, the scandal that's been dubbed Poland's Watergate continues to rumble on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This all concerns Pegasus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It's a powerful software that could be used by clients to remotely hack into someone's mobile phone and access their files, their location, or even take control of the device.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, its owners, the Israeli NSO Group, say that Pegasus can be used by law enforcement agencies to target criminals and terrorists.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But last year, a media investigation revealed that Pegasus had been used to hack opponents in a number of European countries, including France, Hungary and Poland.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now specifically on Poland, those allegations emerged last December and they concern an opposition senator, Krzysztof Błysza.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: There were claims that his mobile phone was hacked and that incriminating messages were illegally taken from them and then used in a smear campaign to try and limit the opposition's chances of winning an election. Well Amnesty International now says it has evidence that two more Polish opponents were also targeted by Pegasus, namely Brzeza's father and his former assistant. Throughout the scandal Poland's government has tried to downplay these allegations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The leader of the ruling Conservative Party has admitted that the country did buy Pegasus, but has denied that it was used on opponents.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: An incendiary investigation has nevertheless been carried out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But around the world, Amnesty says that up to 50,000 mobile phone numbers might have been hacked illegally using this spyware, and that has prompted calls for a European-wide investigation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This week the EU's data protection watchdog called for a ban on Pegasus software, saying that a ban would be the most effective option to protect citizens' fundamental rights.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile Helena, for their part, the Israeli NSA group have denied playing any active role in this ongoing scandal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: They say they are working closely with investigators and have reiterated that they do not have any control about how their clients use Pegasus and the data that they collect.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: All right, Matthew, thanks for bringing us that story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The 72nd Berlin International Film Festival has come to an end

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: and the big winner on the night was Spanish director Carla Simon, who won the prestigious Golden Bear for her film Alcaraz for Morla on the festival.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Let's go over to Berlin and we can speak to David Morrican, the film editor for Ex-Belina magazine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: David, welcome. Good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Carla Simon's film then, was it a surprise?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Did Alcaraz deserve the big prize, would you say?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Good evening, Helena. I would say so.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It was one of the strongest entries in a noticeably weaker competition this year. And it's a beautiful Catalan language drama that follows a family of peach tree farmers who see their land and livelihood threatened by urban developers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It's a very gentle, very bittersweet story that's an incredibly accomplished piece of filmmaking, and the director dedicated it in her speech to people who cultivate the land, which has now become something, as she says, of an act of resistance. So definitely a very worthy winner considering the competition selection this year. And a lot of female talent as well, walking away with prizes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Absolutely. Female filmmakers have dominated the awards this year, winning not only the Golden Bear, but both Gender Neutral Acting awards, the Special Jury Award, which went to Mexican drama, Robe of Gems, and also, of course, the Best Direction Award for Claire Denis, the veteran French filmmaker, for her drama, Both Sides of the Blade, which explores infidelity and how couples can so often poison themselves with the burden of things left unsaid.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And by awarding the Best Director, Best Director, Claire Denis, it has become the third major European festival in a row to award the Direction Award not only to a female filmmaker, but a French female filmmaker following Juliette Cornu and all the D1 last year in Cannes and Venice respectively so yes Claire Denis showing once more that French cinema is thriving and David I'm pointing out the obvious here but of course a difficult year for festival organizers with that word kovat of, but did it feel like the festival was back up on its feet?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Not quite. It's been a very challenging year for them and it was an ambitious gambit to start off with and with a condensed edition, just as many films to see, but on the whole it has run rather smoothly. The on-site testing and the online ticketing system functioned quite well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But it's undeniable that there was a lack of buzz and atmosphere in a noticeably more empty festival.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: So it's a good start. But now all eyes are on next year, which hopefully will be a bit more of a return to normal. We hope that the bears will be back and roaring once again. David Morican, film editor for Ex-Belina magazine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: David, thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now, a government-backed inquiry has found that the Dutch state

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: used extreme violence, often deliberately, during Indonesia's 1940s war for independence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The conclusions of a four-and-a-half-year study contradict authorities in the Netherlands who have long held the position that violence was sporadic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now, the report says that the violence was condoned at every level, politically, militarily and legally. Prime Minister Mark Rutte says the investigation's findings were a reason for him to reiterate previous apologies. Russian figure skater Kamila Valieva missed out on

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: a top three finish in Beijing after a nervy performance in the free skate event. After landing her opening quadruple jump, the 15-year-old fell on several occasions as her routine fell apart.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Now despite the crowd's efforts to rally support, it became clear that a podium position was unlikely and while her positive drug test meant that a gold medal was out of the question, the skating star was visibly upset as she left the ice in fourth position. Her Russian teammates secured gold and silver finishes. Well, coming up, faster, stronger and better than ever, we take a look at the artificial intelligence system out the winter games, tracking athletes' performances like never before. That's ahead. Welcome back to the program. Thanks for joining me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the programme. Thanks for joining me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: From big air to ice skating and ski racing, the jumps, twists and turns of Beijing's Winter Olympic athletes are incredible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And to most of us, it seems impossible to score.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But new technology is making competition judging easier for audiences to understand. And our sports editor, Andy Rubini, explains more now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: experiences to understand. And our sports editor Andy Rubini explains more now. With only a few days to go before the Winter Olympics draw to a close, sports fans from all over the world have been able to enjoy the spectacle in the comfort of their own homes and acquire a better understanding of athletes' performances thanks to the introduction of new technology in Beijing. To find out more about these innovations, we spoke to the CEO of Omega Timing, Alan Zobrist, who with the help of his timekeepers has been providing us with valuable data throughout the Games. Omega is built on its motion sensors and positioning systems introduced in 2018 in Pyeongchang. Now we're using a computer vision and artificial intelligence in order to analyse the entire performance of the athletes and as a consequence explain their result in much greater detail.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We can tell where they gained or lost points or time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Tell me how this could help fans understand these performances.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Typically in figure skating, our computer vision and artificial intelligence systems are analyzing the entire performance of the skaters.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So we would be able to analyze in great detail their jumps, how high, how long, and how fast they jump, and as a consequence really explain the differences of those amazing performances.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: These information are going to be shared as well to athletes and coaches so that they can eventually adapt their training accordingly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Only in the second step we will be working very closely with judges in order to eventually also provide that information to them.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Alan Zobrist and his team of timekeepers have been working around the clock to provide precise numbers in all of the 15 disciplines on show in Beijing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The closing ceremony of the Games takes place on Sunday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And we leave you with a no comment from Thailand where Buddhists are observing Magabuay Day by lighting one million ground lanterns.
